Resource title: Understanding Software Architecture, Quality, and Security Through Code Analysis

By the end of the course, participants will be able to evaluate architectures and integrate these methods within the software development life cycle.

Practicing software architects

Designers and developers of software-reliant systems

Stated learning outcomes:
The goals for 18.06 are using matrices and also understanding them.
Here are key computations and some of the ideas behind them:
    Solving Ax = b for square systems by elimination (pivots, multipliers, back substitution, invertibility of A, factorization into A = LU)
    Complete solution to Ax = b (column space containing b, rank of A, nullspace of A and special solutions to Ax = 0 from row reduced R)
    Basis and dimension (bases for the four fundamental subspaces)
    Least squares solutions (closest line by understanding projections)
    Orthogonalization by Gram-Schmidt (factorization into A = QR)
    Properties of determinants (leading to the cofactor formula and the sum over all n! permutations, applications to inv(A) and volume)
    Eigenvalues and eigenvectors (diagonalizing A, computing powers A^k and matrix exponentials to solve difference and differential equations)
    Symmetric matrices and positive definite matrices (real eigenvalues and orthogonal eigenvectors, tests for x’Ax > 0, applications)
    Linear transformations and change of basis (connected to the Singular Value Decomposition - orthonormal bases that diagonalize A)
    Linear algebra in engineering (graphs and networks, Markov matrices, Fourier matrix, Fast Fourier Transform, linear programming)
Skill area: Demonstrate proficiency in mathematics, including calculus, linear algebra, probability and statistics, and discrete mathematics.

Stated learning outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Collect, organize, and summarize data using appropriate graphical and numerical methods.

Describe and interpret distributions of categorical and quantitative variables in context.

Analyze relationships between variables using tables, graphs, correlation, and regression.

Apply probability concepts and models to assess likelihood and uncertainty.

Explain and use sampling distributions to understand variability and make statistical judgments.

Perform statistical inference, including confidence intervals and hypothesis tests, and interpret results in context.

Evaluate data-based claims critically, recognizing limitations, sources of bias, and the difference between association and causation.
Intended audience: Students with no prior knowledge in statistics
Skill area: Demonstrate proficiency in mathematics, including calculus, linear algebra, probability and statistics, and discrete mathematics.

Stated learning outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Explain foundational concepts of causation, including deterministic and indeterministic causal relationships among variables.

Distinguish between causation and association, and explain why associations do not necessarily imply causal relationships.

Analyze relative and conditional frequencies to assess association and independence between variables.

Use causal graphs to represent causal assumptions and reason about relationships among variables.

Apply concepts of conditional independence and d-separation to evaluate causal structures and implied associations.

Identify and explain challenges in causal inference, including confounding and limitations of causal discovery from observational data.

Evaluate causal claims and strategies, including the role of interventions and experiments, using formal reasoning and real-world case studies.
Length (mins): A semester long, at the pace of one or two modules per week.
Intended audience: students interested in critical thinking skills for daily life, students who will take a few statistics courses in service of a related field of study, and/or students interested in the foundations of quantitative causal models
Skill area: Other (Specify in the 'Comments' column)
Comments: Prepares students for research and critical thinking from a statistical and causal angle.

Resource title: CERT Applied Data Science for Cybersecurity Certificate Examination
Stated learning outcomes: This examination provides an objective validation of conceptual knowledge and practical understanding of data analysis for cybersecurity from netflow, malware, and digital forensics activity, as presented in the required courses. The examination consists of 60 multiple choice questions. Students proceed through the examination at their convenience over four hours.
Stated prerequisites: Before registering for this exam, participants must complete the prerequisite courses: Fundamentals of Statistics Applied to Cybersecurity, Advanced Analytics: Netflow, Advanced Analytics: Malware, and Advanced Analytics: Digital Forensics.
Intended audience:
This validation exam is required for professionals who wish to pursue the following SEI credentials:

CERT Applied Data Science for Cybersecurity Professional Certificate Program

Resource title: CERT Secure Coding in C and C++ Professional Certificate
Stated learning outcomes:
Students will acquire a working knowledge of common programming errors that lead to software vulnerabilities, how these errors can be exploited, and effective mitigation strategies for preventing the introduction of these errors. In particular, students will learn how to
improve the overall security of any C or C++ application
thwart buffer overflows and stack-smashing attacks that exploit insecure string manipulation logic
avoid vulnerabilities and security flaws resulting from the incorrect use of dynamic memory management functions
eliminate integer-related problems: integer overflows, sign errors, and truncation errors
correctly use formatted output functions without introducing format-string vulnerabilities
avoid I/O vulnerabilities, including race conditions
Stated prerequisites:
A basic to intermediate understanding of the C and C++ programming languages
Software security knowledge or experience is not required
Skill area: Demonstrate the ability to apply programming skills and software engineering knowledge, including data structures and algorithms, to practical problems.

Stated learning outcomes:

improve the overall security of any Java application
avoid injection attacks, such as SQL injection and XSS
understand Java's memory model, with a thorough grounding of concurrency, and learn how to prevent race conditions while avoiding deadlock
learn when to throw and catch exceptions
avoid I/O vulnerabilities, including file-based race conditions
learn how historical exploits on Java were executed and later disabled
Stated prerequisites:
A basic to intermediate understanding of the Java programming language
Software security knowledge or experience is not required

This unit covers the technical skills required to construct argument diagrams using software, including mapping complex structures, linked premises, and implied claims. Students will learn to evaluate arguments for validity and strength using deductive and non-deductive reasoning. Finally, the material applies these skills to analyze public arguments by identifying rhetorical elements and diagramming longer texts.

This course prepares students to make rational decisions regarding their personal lives and social policy while developing the ability to critically assess claims in media and discussions. Students will explore foundational concepts including causation, association, and independence. Additionally, the curriculum covers strategies for navigating the challenges of inferring causation from association.

Stated learning outcomes: This course provides a comprehensive foundation in formal logic, beginning with the core concepts of statements and arguments before progressing through the syntax, semantics, and proof systems of sentential logic. Students develop the ability to symbolize natural language into logical formulae, construct truth tables, and build formal derivations using inference rules. The course then extends these skills into predicate logic, where students learn to handle quantifiers, variables, and more complex logical structures. Advanced topics including identity, functions, and metamathematical concepts round out the course, equipping students with rigorous tools for logical analysis and proof construction.
Skill area: Apply logical and critical thinking to evaluate evidence, assumptions, and implications of academic arguments and engineering decisions.
Comments: Has a cost attached to it

Stated learning outcomes: This course equips students with the tools to conduct structured public policy analysis in engineering and technology contexts. Students learn to assess the accuracy and completeness of policy-relevant information, develop neutral policy questions, and evaluate competing solutions against criteria of effectiveness, efficiency, equity, and political acceptability. The course applies these skills consistently across a range of real-world engineering domains including cybersecurity, renewable energy, electric vehicles, and water desalination, bridging the gap between technical expertise and policy decision-making.
Skill area: Anticipate and mitigate potential issues related to usability, security, and ethics in problem-solving.

Stated learning outcomes:
By the end of this lecture, students should be able to:

Define content validity and distinguish it from other forms of validity to establish its importance in research.

Design a content validation study by selecting appropriate judges and structuring surveys to gather expert feedback.

Apply quantitative metrics to evaluate how well scale items match their intended definitions and distinguish them from related concepts.
Stated prerequisites: A background in psychometrics and statistics, referencing concepts like Confirmatory Factor Analysis and Analysis of Variance
Skill area: Apply logical and critical thinking to evaluate evidence, assumptions, and implications of academic arguments and engineering decisions.
Comments: The presentation is a workshop companion to the Colquitt et al. (2019) paper on Content Validation Guidelines. It utilizes a continuous Running Example of a construct called Scholarly Orientation to demonstrate concepts.

Resource title: Recommendations for Discouraging, Identifying, and Removing Dirty Data in Survey Research
Skill area: Apply logical and critical thinking to evaluate evidence, assumptions, and implications of academic arguments and engineering decisions.

Resource title: Reflexivity in Research Methods: Boundary Theory and the Researcher Role Continuum
Stated learning outcomes:
By the end of this lecture, students should be able to:

Define reflexivity and positionality to articulate how a researcher's identity and biases influence the research process.

Apply the Researcher Role Continuum to categorize their own position (e.g., Outsider, Insider, Liminal) relative to their study participants.

Analyze the boundaries between their personal and professional identities to manage potential spillover and ethical challenges in fieldwork.
Stated prerequisites: The content assumes familiarity with qualitative research methods, identity theory, and boundary theory.
Skill area: Apply logical and critical thinking to evaluate evidence, assumptions, and implications of academic arguments and engineering decisions.
Comments: This lecture utilizes the "Researcher Role Continuum" and boundary theory to help scholars examine how their personal identities and positionality inescapably influence their research process.
